title: Financial literacy grants for VIC music businesses
description: This program provides VIC music businesses with funding to help them implement programs and processes or get advice to help control their finances better.
whoCanApply: Victorian-based small to medium music businesses.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $1,000 and consultations with financial and business experts.
overview: The Leg Up program consists of: Grant Stream – there are 20 grants of up to $1,000 for expenses that will help with controlling finances, e.g. hardware, software, platform subscriptions, advice Consultation Stream – financial health checks to discuss tax planning, royalty accounting, business structure or any other topics. Applicants may apply for one or both of these streams. This program is only open to Victorian-based music businesses.
whoCanApplyDetail: Victorian-based small to medium music businesses.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of up to $1,000 and consultations with financial and business experts.

apply.text: Apply for the Leg Up VIC
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for WA based companies in the mining equipment, technology and services (METS) sector
description: This program provides funding to METS companies to help them develop products and services in certain focus areas.
whoCanApply: Western Australian companies in the METS sector.
whatYouGet: Matched funding of up to $250,000 per approved project.
overview: This program aims to activate innovation and research into the following focus areas: net zero emission mining critical minerals green steel exploration amplification alternative use of tailings and waste precision and low impact mining. Eligible projects must meet the definition of minerals research as outlined in the guidelines. To be eligible, businesses must: provide mining equipment, technology or services to the mining sector be based in Western Australia have an Australian business number (ABN) be registered for goods and services tax (GST) have an annual turnover of less than $50 million per annum be a company incorporated in Australia or an incorporated trustee applying on behalf of a trust.
whoCanApplyDetail: Western Australian companies in the METS sector.
whatYouGetDetail: Matched funding of up to $250,000 per approved project.

title: Funding for Aboriginal Territorians and Aboriginal owned businesses developing cultural tourism experiences
programName: Aboriginal Tourism Development Support Grants NT
description: Funding is available to assist Aboriginal Territorians and Aboriginal owned businesses and organisations to develop Aboriginal cultural tourism experiences and products that encourage visitors to travel to the NT and stay longer.
whoCanApply: Aboriginal organisations.
whatYouGet: Funding from between $10,000 and $30,000.
overview: Funding is offered to assist the engagement of professional services to support feasibility studies and business planning. Professional services can also be engaged to assist in preparing applications to the relevant land council or other land management authority for tourism experiences and product/s. To be eligible, applicants must: be greater than 50% Aboriginal owned be an Aboriginal owned business or organisation located and operating in the NT be legally constituted be Australian registered have no outstanding grant acquittals.
whoCanApplyDetail: Aboriginal organisations.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding from between $10,000 and $30,000.

description: Aboriginal Tourism Grants provide Northern Territory Aboriginal owned and operated tourism businesses with funding to improve their business.
whoCanApply: Northern Territory Aboriginal owned and operated tourism businesses.
whatYouGet: Funding of between $30,000 and $100,000.
overview: Funding is available for: developing and activating new bookable Aboriginal cultural tourism products upgrading improvements and/or new infrastructure for tourism visitor experiences infrastructure to support sustainability and/or accessibility and inclusion objectives Interpretative signage, interpretation planning and guiding manuals implementation of new technology to improve on-ground tourism visitor experience engaging expert and specialist professionals to support the development and delivery of activities. To be eligible, your tourism business must: be greater than 50% Aboriginal owned be an Aboriginal owned business or organisation located and operating in the NT have a significant tourism focus be legally constituted have approvals of the relevant Land Council or other land management authority for current and proposed/new tourism product/s related to the application be Australian registered.
whoCanApplyDetail: Northern Territory Aboriginal owned and operated tourism businesses.

title: Funding for NSW First Nations-led music programs and resources
programName: Contemporary Music Development Grants – First Nations Industry Development NSW
description: This program provides funding for First Nations NSW led music businesses and organisations with a track record of delivering significant outcomes for First Nations contemporary music in NSW.
whoCanApply: First Nations NSW led music businesses or organisations.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $150,000.
overview: Funding can support the following activities: skills, training and capacity building programs for artists, industry professionals and music businesses programs to upskill industry professionals and music businesses in best practice and emerging trends and technologies including AI, marketing and promotion, cultural literacy and safety programs and resources to improve well-being, support workplace and audience safety, accessibility, cultural safety and working with young people industry-led marketing campaigns to promote music in NSW initiatives that cultivate innovation, collaboration and partnerships locally and internationally industry-led research and advocacy. This program is open to First Nations NSW led music businesses or organisations that demonstrate an established ongoing connection to community through their work. To be eligible to receive funding, applicants must: have a governing body that is majority First Nations people be currently based in NSW or deliver a significant contribution to the NSW contemporary music sector be an incorporated entity or trust (including a trust with a corporate or individual trustee) and hold an Australian business number (ABN), Australian company number (ACN), or be registered with NSW Fair Trading under the Associations Incorporation Act 2009 or the Co-operatives National Law (NSW) set out in the appendix to the Co-operatives (Adoption of National Law) Act 2012.
whoCanApplyDetail: First Nations NSW led music businesses or organisations.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of up to $150,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Contemporary Music Development Grants – First Nations Industry Development NSW
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for NSW First Nations artists and acts
programName: Contemporary Music Development Grants – First Nations Creative and Professional Development NSW
description: This program provides funding to First Nations artists and acts with an existing body of work in contemporary music to support creation, recording, and promotion of new and original contemporary music, professional development and the purchase of equipment.
whoCanApply: First Nations artists and acts in NSW.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $30,000.
overview: This funding aims to: prioritise and protect First Nations music strengthen the recorded music ecosystem for First Nations artists future-proof the NSW music industry for First Nations artists through upskilling and collaboration build the profile of First Nations NSW music. This program is open to First Nations artists and acts, as well as music businesses applying on behalf of an artist or act. Applicants may include, an artist who: identifies as Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander is 18 years or older currently lives in NSW (minimum 12 months) performs new and original contemporary music has at least one publicly available release. An act: with majority Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander members with members who are all 18 years or older with at least 50% of members currently living in NSW (minimum 12 months) that performs new and original contemporary music that has at least one publicly available release.
whoCanApplyDetail: First Nations artists and acts in NSW.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of up to $30,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Contemporary Music Development Grants – First Nations Creative and Professional Development NSW
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

description: This program provides support for industry-led programs and resources that build the capacity of artists, industry professionals and music businesses, address best practice and emerging trends, promote music in NSW and deliver research and advocacy.
whoCanApply: Music businesses and organisations.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $150,000.
overview: This funding program is designed for music businesses and organisations with a track record of delivering significant outcomes for contemporary music in NSW, and aims to: develop skills and capacity for artists and acts upskill industry professionals and music businesses in best practice and emerging trends improve industry standards build the profile of the NSW music industry cultivate innovation, collaboration and partnership support industry-led research and advocacy strengthen communities. This program is open to music businesses or organisations. Funding recipients must be: currently based in NSW or deliver a significant contribution to the NSW contemporary music sector be an incorporated entity or trust (including a trust with a corporate or individual trustee) and hold an Australian business number (ABN), Australian company number (ACN), or be registered with NSW Fair Trading under the Associations Incorporation Act 2009 or the Co-operatives National Law (NSW) set out in the appendix to the Co-operatives (Adoption of National Law) Act 2012.
whoCanApplyDetail: Music businesses and organisations.

programName: Contemporary Music Development Grants – Recording, Content and Promotion NSW
description: This program provides grants to artists and acts to support career sustainability through creation, recording and promotion of new and original contemporary music.
whoCanApply: NSW artists and acts with an existing body of work in contemporary music.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $30,000.
overview: This funding aims to: strengthen the recorded music ecosystem future proof the NSW music industry through upskilling and collaboration build the profile of NSW music. This program is open to artists, acts and music businesses applying on behalf of an artist or act. Funding recipients must: be 18 years or older currently live in NSW (minimum 12 months) perform new and original contemporary music or represent an artist or act creating and/or performing new and original contemporary music have publicly available releases. Applicants will need: an active Australian business number (ABN) a bank account with the same name as your ABN or a funds administrator to help you out.

title: Funding for venues to engage consultants and experts
description: Funding is available to support venues getting advice from consultants and experts to create fit for purpose venues.
whoCanApply: NSW live music venues.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $20,000.
overview: Venues who demonstrate a commitment to increasing live music programming may apply for grants to support advice from consultants and experts to create fit for purpose venues. Examples of activities which may be funded include: reports applications planning expenses legal services audits. For the purpose of this program, a contemporary live music venue refers to a venue that: is licensed or unlicensed has a room or space dedicated to live music that is a significant part (eg. more than 50%) of the venue and contains appropriate infrastructure to support regular performances, for example, a separate auditorium, lighting, a sound desk, etc has formal arrangements in place establishing payments for artist performances has ongoing and regular live music programming programs artists and acts performing new and original contemporary music. Applicants must be either an incorporated entity or trust holding an Australian business number or Australian company number, or they must be registered with NSW Fair Trading. To be eligible, applicants must: hold a lease or occupancy agreement with at least 2 years from the application close date remaining of the current term (where the premises aren’t owned by the operator) provide a support letter from premises (building) owner for proposed grant where premises not owned by the applicant hold a OneMusic licence.
whoCanApplyDetail: NSW live music venues.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of up to $20,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Venue Upgrade Grants Program 1 NSW
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for professional development of young and emerging artists
programName: Young and Emerging Artist Professional Development Program TAS
description: This program provides support for young and emerging artists and arts workers to undertake professional and skills development activities.
whoCanApply: Young and emerging Tasmanian artists.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $16,000.
overview: Activities which may be funded include: residency costs masterclass fees mentoring fees travel and accommodation costs (including per diems) disability access costs (including travel costs for carers) materials (including art form materials) costs associated with child or dependent care. To be eligible, applicants must be an individual artist or arts worker who is either aged 25 years or younger, or is in the first 5 years of their professional practice. Applicants to Arts Tasmania grant and funding programs generally must also be: individual artists and arts workers who have lived in Tasmania for 6 of the last 12 months groups of artists or arts workers with at least one Tasmanian member Tasmanian organisations that are registered under law (an incorporated association, or a company limited by guarantee) or created by law (a government statutory authority).

title: Funding to hold Aboriginal key cultural events and activities in NSW
programName: Aboriginal Affairs NSW Cultural Grants Program
description: This program provides funding to Aboriginal community organisations across NSW to celebrate Aboriginal culture and hold key cultural events and activities.
whoCanApply: Eligible NSW Aboriginal owned and controlled organisations.
whatYouGet: Funding between $500 to $20,000.
overview: Funding can be used for projects that meet the objectives of the Cultural Grants Program. The following are the types of activities that may be funded, where they are aligned with the program objectives: women’s or men’s gathering on Country delivery of a culture and wellbeing camp for Aboriginal youth creation of a digital installation showing Aboriginal history of the local community statewide music or cultural festival hosting a series of online workshops. Small community-based Aboriginal-owned and controlled organisations are able to access this fund. Applicants must: be an eligible Aboriginal-owned and controlled organisation deliver a service to Aboriginal communities within NSW have public liability insurance of at least $10 million per claim, or be willing to purchase it as part of the project budget. Eligible organisations are: registered Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Corporations companies incorporated in Australia Local Aboriginal Land Councils incorporated associations incorporated cooperatives incorporated trustees on behalf of a trust unincorporated Aboriginal community groups with an eligible auspice Aboriginal businesss or sole traders whose primary business activity relates to cultural expression or revitalisation (noting projects must not be profit-making in nature).
whoCanApplyDetail: Eligible NSW Aboriginal owned and controlled organisations.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding between $500 to $20,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Aboriginal Affairs NSW Cultural Grants Program
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

overview: Funding is available for projects that support the: delivery of innovative community engagement regarding varroa mite development of innovative varroa mite management and monitoring tools. title: Funding for TAS organisations to install or upgrade electric vehicle charging infrastructure
programName: Electric Vehicle ChargeSmart Grants Program TAS
description: This program provides TAS organisations with funding to help with the costs of purchasing, installing or upgrading electric vehicle charging infrastructure.
whoCanApply: Tasmanian businesses, not-for-profits and other organisations.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $50,000.
overview: Funding is available to support the upfront cost of purchasing and installing or upgrading existing electric vehicle fast charging infrastructure in Tasmania for public use. This funding round aims to: address gaps in the existing EV fast charging network install new charging stations in cities and arterial routes increase the capacity of existing stations (upgrades). To be eligible, you must be located in Tasmania and be one of the following entity types: local government agencies and bodies not-for-profit incorporated organisations not-for-profit organisations or community groups that are not incorporated, if sponsored by an incorporated organisation for-profit incorporated organisations businesses with an active Australian business number (ABN) before 1 January 2025.

title: Funding for Victorian distillers
programName: Distillery Support – Business Growth Fit-for-Purpose Grant VIC
description: This program provides funding for tailored projects designed to help distillers take the next step in the development of their business.
whoCanApply: Victorian distillers.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $200,000.
overview: Funding may be used for the following types of projects: plant and equipment to facilitate growth and competitiveness of businesses to meet demand and improve cost technology adoption (excluding ongoing maintenance and service support costs) to increase business efficiency items that support product diversification and new product development items that build on the Hazardous Areas and Dangerous Goods Audit (HADGA), or general safety improvements at the distillery not eligible under the HADGA items that enhance sustainability including electrification, greenhouse gas emission reduction, energy saving, waste reduction, water reduction activities that increase export capability marketing activities that increase consumer awareness of your product. To be eligible, applicants must: have a current Australian business number (ABN) be registered as a business in Victoria be a legal entity own at least one still with a capacity of 50L or more hold a valid ATO Manufacturer's Licence to produce distilled alcoholic beverages hold a current General, Producer's or Seller's liquor licence issued by Liquor Control Victoria be able to meet the agreed (minimum 30 or 50%) cash co-contribution requirement.
whoCanApplyDetail: Victorian distillers.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of up to $200,000.

title: Funding for established Victorian music festival organisers
description: This program provides funding to established Victorian music festival organisers to support them to stage new or existing events.
whoCanApply: Victorian music festival organisers.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $50,000 per festival.
overview: This grant program aims to support the economic sustainability of ticketed contemporary music festivals in Victoria: with a capacity of 1000+ attendees run by experienced and established Victorian festival organisers with a proven track record. Funding can be used for costs associated with the planning and delivery of the festival, including: artists marketing production operations travel access. To be eligible, you must be an experienced organiser of ticketed contemporary live music festivals which: are located in Victoria and hold an Australian business number (ABN) may include promoters, not-for-profit organisations, artists/bands or other music industry businesses and organisations have the rights to deliver a live music festival in Victoria with an in-person capacity of over 1000 people.
whoCanApplyDetail: Victorian music festival organisers.

title: Funding for exploration drilling projects in Tasmania
description: This program provides funding for co-funded greenfields exploration drilling projects in Tasmania.
whoCanApply: TAS explorers and prospectors.
whatYouGet: Funding up to $70,000 for drilling costs, plus an additional $20,000 if helicopter support is required.
overview: The EDGI provides explorers with co-funding to undertake greenfields exploration in Tasmania, especially for minerals included on the 2024 Australian Critical Minerals list. Preference will be given to high-quality, technically and economically sound projects that promote innovative exploration or new exploratory concepts and technology. To be eligible, applicants must: hold an Exploration Licence, Special Exploration Licence, Retention Licence, or Mining Lease covering the project's location (consideration may be given to those with an Exploration Licence application pending) be the entity which holds the tenement and licence, or lease be aged over 18 years be registered for tax purposes in Australia have an active Australian business number (ABN).
whoCanApplyDetail: TAS explorers and prospectors.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding up to $70,000 for drilling costs, plus an additional $20,000 if helicopter support is required.

programName: Electric Vehicle Destination Charging Grants NSW
description: This program provides funding to private CPOs to own and operate public EV fast chargers across regional NSW.
whoCanApply: Eligible private CPOs operating across regional NSW.
whatYouGet: Funding amounts vary.
overview: Co-funding is available to assist eligible private EV CPOs to own and operate lower powered direct current (DC) public EV fast chargers at council and business-owned tourism sites across regional NSW. This funding round prioritises the installation of 24kW to 100kW DC EV charging infrastructure along established NSW road trip routes across regional NSW. To be eligible for co-funding, applicants must be a charge point operator that is either: an entity incorporated under the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) a state-owned corporation or subsidiary of an Australian state or territory owned corporation.

The Forestry Business Support package is part of a suite of programs on offer to support sawmill businesses, harvest and/or haulage contractors, community forestry operators and other forest-based businesses impacted by the native transition. title: Support for businesses in far west NSW impacted by the major electrical outage from 17 October 2024
programName: Small-Medium Business Power Outage Support Grant NSW
description: A one-off payment for businesses directly impacted by the power outage in the far west region of NSW.
whoCanApply: Businesses in the Far West of NSW and the town of Cockburn, SA, impacted by the major electrical outage.
whatYouGet: $400 one-off payment.
overview: Financial support is available to businesses in the Far West of NSW impacted by the major electrical outage from the Far West Region Storm from 17 October 2024 (AGRN 1149). The payment is to help with out-of-pocket expenses incurred as a result of the power outage. To be eligible, your business must: have an active Australian business number (ABN) registered before 17 October 2024 have been operating in a local government area listed under disaster declaration AGRN 1149 or the town of Cockburn, South Australia, on 17 October 2024 employ no more than 200 full-time employees (or equivalent).

title: Funding for First Nations small businesses impacted by Ex-Tropical Cyclone Ellie flooding
programName: Aboriginal and Local Business Participation in Recovery Program WA
description: This program provides funding to First Nations owned small businesses to help them recover from the impacts of flooding associated with Ex-Tropical Cyclone Ellie in WA from 28 December 2022 onwards.
whoCanApply: Aboriginal-owned small businesses impacted by the Fitzroy Valley flooding from 28 December 2022 onwards.
whatYouGet: Funding varies
overview: Grants are available to support Aboriginal-owned small businesses and sole traders in the economic recovery of the Fitzroy Valley following the flooding associated with Ex-Tropical Cyclone Ellie. Funding available includes: Services and training grants up to $25,000 to cover non-capital costs for business establishment or growth such as insurance, business accreditation and training. Equipment and asset grants of up to $100,000 to assist with the hire, lease or purchase of specialist assets or items to undertake recovery works delivery. To be eligible, applicants must be an Aboriginal-owned small business or trading enterprise that: is registered with Supply Nation, Aboriginal Business Directory WA or Office of the Registrar of Indigenous Corporations operates and is located in the Shire of Derby-West Kimberley (SDWK) can demonstrate 2 years history of regularly providing goods and services to customers located in the SDWK has an active Australian business number (ABN).
whoCanApplyDetail: Aboriginal-owned small businesses impacted by the Fitzroy Valley flooding from 28 December 2022 onwards.

title: Funding for primary producers, grower groups within the Eyre Peninsula and SA Arid Lands
programName: Eyre Peninsula and SA Arid Lands Flood Recovery Primary Producer Grant
description: This program provides funding to primary producers, grower groups and farming system groups within the Eyre Peninsula and SA Arid Lands to help them manage biosecurity risks.
whoCanApply: Primary production enterprises within the Eyre Peninsula and SA Arid Lands.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $40,000.
overview: This program has been created to enable impacted primary producers, grower groups and farming system groups involved in invasive species management, operating within the Cleve, Franklin Harbour, Gawler Ranges and Kimba districts to manage biosecurity risks arising from the major rainfall event. Funding can be used to improve biosecurity outcomes for eligible primary production enterprises, including but not limited to: rehabilitation costs baiting programs fencing and infrastructure monitoring technology training and licensing weed control equipment. To be eligible, applicants must: be a primary producer or a farmer organisation, operating within an eligible area hold an Australian business number (ABN) be registered for goods and services tax (GST) or be a not-for-profit organisation.

title: Funding for QLD rural landholders for clean and reinstatement activities
programName: Rural Landholder Recovery Grant Scheme QLD
description: This program provides funding for clean-up and reinstatement activities to help rural landholders recover from 2023-24 disaster events.
whoCanApply: QLD rural landholders impacted by an eligible disaster.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $10,000.
overview: Funding is available for rural landholders located with local government areas activated for a 2023-24 disaster event. Grants may be used to help pay for clean-up and reinstatement costs, including but not limited to: removing and disposing of flood related debris or damaged goods and materials removing and disposing of dead livestock, dangerous trees purchasing, hiring or leasing equipment or materials to clean a property, premises or equipment salvaging crops, grain or feed, or purchasing fodder to replace stock lost as a result of the event repairing or reinstating uninsured, flood damaged sheds, water tanks and water for stock, feed trays or fencing on the property, to pre-disaster standard only (excludes houses). To be eligible, applicants must: be the owner or lessee under a long term lease, of land of at least 10 hectares (24.7 acres) in the defined disaster area on which the applicant operates a primary production enterprise hold an Australian business number (ABN), and have held that ABN at the time of the natural disaster in the financial year, have earned at least $20,000 gross income from the primary production enterprise on the affected property have been engaged in carrying on the primary production enterprise when affected by an eligible disaster intend to re-establish the primary production enterprise in the defined disaster area for an eligible disaster.
whoCanApplyDetail: QLD rural landholders impacted by an eligible disaster.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of up to $10,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Rural Landholder Recovery Grant Scheme QLD
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

description: This program provides funding to TAS multicultural small businesses to help them grow their business.

overview: Funding can be used to obtain business advice or support from a suitably qualified service provider to get help with: financial planning risk management business planning marketing activities diversification or innovation planning other activities, including training fees, conference tickets, installing and upgrading software licences. To be eligible, you must: be registered for tax purposes in Australia, with an Australian business number (ABN) be a small business with no more than 19 FTE employees demonstrate that the business is currently operating and located in Tasmania be an Australian citizen, permanent resident or have the right visa to run a business in Australia and be able to demonstrate you arrived in Australia in the last 10 years demonstrate an annual sales turnover of at $40,000 in the 2022-23 or 2023-24 financial year be able to make the required cash co-contribution.

title: Payments for WA small businesses and charitable organisations operating in embedded networks
description: This program provides energy bill relief for WA small businesses and charitable organisations operating in embedded networks.
whoCanApply: WA small businesses and charitable organisations.
whatYouGet: One-off payment of $725.
overview: Energy rebates are available to small businesses and charitable organisations that operate in embedded networks in WA. Embedded networks include examples such as: shopping centres businesses operating from airports ports and industrial parks businesses that have a sub-meter linked to a master meter controlled by the landlord other circumstances where landlords purchase electricity from energy providers and on-sell the electricity to tenants. To be eligible, applicants must: have held a valid and active Australian business number (ABN) as a small business or charity on 17 June 2024 and for the period covered by their application be a small business or charity consuming less than 50 megawatt hours (MWh) of electricity per year, or where this is not measured, be liable for less than $15,000 per annum in electricity costs have been incurring electricity costs on 17 June 2024 occupy a commercial premises as a tenant or owner not be directly billed by Synergy or Horizon Power be receiving power on-supplied via an embedded network/submetering arrangement. Additionally, if not in an embedded network, applicants must fall within the scope of one of the following electricity retail tariff classes: C1 or C2 – special community service tariff D1 or D2 – special tariff for certain premises L1 or L2 – general supply R1 or R2 – time of use tariff.
whoCanApplyDetail: WA small businesses and charitable organisations.
whatYouGetDetail: One-off payment of $725.

To be eligible, applicants must: be a sole operator or a small business employing 19 or fewer full-time equivalent employees (FTEs) hold an Australian business number (ABN) at the time of the severe weather event commencing 26 August 2024 have suffered direct damage to premises and/or tools be claiming for costs relating to clean-up activities be primarily responsible for meeting the costs claimed.

title: Funding for carbon planting projects
programName: Living Carbon Grants – The Riverina LLS Region
description: This program provides NSW landholders with funding to help them start a carbon planting project.
whoCanApply: Landholders in the Riverina Local Land Services region of NSW.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $200,000.
overview: Funding is available for environmental planting projects of up to 200 hectares in size that focus on revegetating habitats for iconic and threatened species. Eligible costs include: soil preparation (such as through ripping or augering) fencing materials and labour for standard stock fences, funded up to 50% of the total fencing costs, not exceeding 50% of your total grant request direct seeding costs, seeds and direct seeding tube stock tree protection material such as tree guards planting of tube stock, including the installation of tree protection Australian Carbon Credit Unit Scheme (ACCU) Scheme and Accounting for Nature (AfN) costs, set funding amount of $5000. To be eligible, applicants must be located in the NSW Riverina Local Land Services region, and be one of the following: a private landholder who is the proponent of the registered carbon project an Aboriginal organisation or Traditional Owner group that owns or has legal right to the land and who are the proponent of the registered carbon project a public land manager with pre-application approval from the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water.
whoCanApplyDetail: Landholders in the Riverina Local Land Services region of NSW.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of up to $200,000.

programName: Unlocking Aboriginal Tourism Development Funding NT
description: This program provides NT Aboriginal owned tourism related businesses with access to consultancy services.
whoCanApply: NT Aboriginal owned tourism related businesses.
whatYouGet: Consultancy services.
overview: Support is available to help tourism related businesses access consultancy services, which may be used to help them navigate and access potential funding opportunities. This initiative will focus on support for new or enhanced existing product offerings and experiences, including: new product capital enhanced visitor experiences including infrastructure improvements business development through improvement in systems and processes, e.g. booking systems workforce development marketing that supports potential engagement with new markets and trade distribution partners. There are 2 levels of consultancy services available: Level 1 – advice and initial assistance about potential funding availability, up to a maximum of 2 hours Levels 2 – funding application preparation service, including assistance in writing submissions up to a maximum of 16 hours. To be eligible, applicants must be: greater than 50% Aboriginal owned an Aboriginal owned business or organisation located and operating in the NT legally constituted Australian registered. If applying as an active trading Aboriginal tourism business, you must: have a current Australian Tourism Data Warehouse (ATDW) listing or have applied for one at the time of application be a member of a peak industry body employ Territory residents.

To be eligible, applicants must: have a significant tourism focus operating in and employing resident Territorians be legally constituted and registered in Australia have a current Australian Tourism Data Warehouse (ATDW) listing be project ready and have funds available to commence the project have the funding available for the matched contribution be a member of a peak industry body.

whatYouGet: Matched funding of up to $10,000.
overview: This program is designed to cater for both large and small events, with 2 tiers of funding providing options for events with either intrastate or interstate visitation targets. Tier 1 funding of between $2,500 and $5,000 for applicants undertaking intrastate marketing activities seeking to attract visitors from outside their region. Tier 2 funding of between $5,001 and $10,000 for applicants undertaking interstate marketing activities seeking to attract visitors from outside Tasmania. To be eligible, applicants must: be registered for tax purposes in Australia with a continuously active Australian business number (ABN) on or before 30 June 2024 be an event organiser, delivering an event in Tasmania between 1 January and 30 June 2025 submit an application at least 6 weeks prior to the event commencing. The event must not be a new event – it must have been held previously.

whoCanApply: NSW businesses.
whatYouGet: Funding varies.
overview: The grant is provided in two stages: up to $4,000, covering up to 75% of the costs, to identify the key actions needed to advance your business’ net zero journey up to $26,000, covering up to 75% of costs, to support detailed work such as developing a greenhouse gas inventory, formulating a net zero action plan or implementing other eligible activities. To be eligible, applicants must: have an Australian business number (ABN) and be registered for goods and services tax (GST) be a business with a NSW site address and business operations in NSW not be a safeguard facility under the Australian Government’s Safeguard Mechanism spend at least $200,000 annually on energy bills at a single site in NSW or a total of $500,000 across multiple sites in NSW not have already been approved for grant funding under the Net Zero Planning Grant, nor be a related entity to an entity or entities that have been successful in applying for this Grant, unless the main business operations in NSW of the related entities fall under different industry classification groups.

title: Funding for SA based business impacted by the Whyalla Steelworks challenges
programName: Whyalla Small Local Business Support Grant SA
description: This program supports Whyalla-based businesses and not-for-profits that have experienced a reduction in revenue as a result of the decline in activity at the Steelworks.
whoCanApply: Whyalla-based businesses and not-for-profits.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $10,000.
overview: Funding is available to support SA, Whyalla-based businesses and not-for-profit organisations that have experienced a material reduction in revenue as a result of the broader community impact arising from the recent decline in activity at OneSteel and its related businesses. Eligible expenses include: meeting standing business costs, including utilities, salaries and rent; seeking financial advice to support the recovery of the business; adjusting the business to be viable in the changed local context; developing the business and extending business reach through marketing and communications activities; and retaining, staying connected to, and supporting existing employees. To be eligible, applicants must: be a legal entity established in Australia be a SA business that is conducting business operations and have their principal place of business registered at a premises within the City of Whyalla as at 1 February 2025 have an active Australian business number (ABN) as at 1 February 2025 be registered for goods and services tax (GST) have an Australia-wide grouped payroll of less than $1.5 million in 2023-24 demonstrate a decline in revenue of 20% or more in any consecutive 3-month period within the 9 months prior to 19 February 2025, compared to the same 3-month period in the year prior (the ‘comparative period’).
whoCanApplyDetail: Whyalla-based businesses and not-for-profits.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of up to $10,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Whyalla Small Local Business Support Grant SA

title: Rebates for purchasing and installing eID tagging systems
programName: Sheep and Goat Electronic Identification (eID) Rebate QLD
description: Rebates are available for primary producers and livestock agents to help with the costs of implementing eID tagging systems.
whoCanApply: QLD primary producers and livestock agents.
whatYouGet: Rebate of up to $1600.
overview: Industry and government have agreed to transition towards mandatory electronic identification (eID) for sheep and farmed goats nation-wide. The Queensland Sheep and Goat eID Assistance Package will provide: a 50% rebate up to $1600 (per Property Identification Code (PIC) based in Queensland) to sheep and managed goat producers for eID readers and eID devices a 50% rebate up to $1600 to Queensland livestock agents for eID readers. To be eligible for assistance, primary producers must meet the following conditions: have a property identification code (PIC) based in Queensland have 30 or more sheep or managed goats have a current and up-to-date biosecurity entity registration must not have claimed assistance through any other Queensland Government eID funding have purchased an approved device or an electronic reader (or a combination of both) on or after 1 January 2023. To be eligible for a rebate as a livestock agent, applicants must: have an Australian business number (ABN) have an NLIS account with recorded movement of sheep or managed goats off a PIC in the previous 12 months gave purchased an electronic reader on or after 1 January 2023.
whoCanApplyDetail: QLD primary producers and livestock agents.
whatYouGetDetail: Rebate of up to $1600.

description: The Biz Secure program provides Northern Territory businesses with funding to help them improve the safety and security of their premises against break-ins.
whoCanApply: Northern Territory businesses wanting to protect their premises from break-ins.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $15,000 for individual businesses and $50,000 for clusters of businesses.
overview: Individual businesses or a cluster of businesses can apply to receive a voucher to undertake an independent security audit and to implement one or more of the recommended eligible security improvement jobs. To be eligible, you must: be incorporated under an Act of the Northern Territory (NT) or the Commonwealth, or are a sole trader or partnership operating with a NT registered business name be physically located in the NT operate from commercial premises offer services to customers from a shopfront premises or have at least one external publicly accessible entry/exit point offer goods and/or services to the public have no more than 100 employees have been incorporated/registered, and hold a valid Australian business number (ABN).
whoCanApplyDetail: Northern Territory businesses wanting to protect their premises from break-ins.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of up to $15,000 for individual businesses and $50,000 for clusters of businesses.

apply.text: Apply for the Biz Secure NT
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for Skills Tasmania endorsed registered training organisations
description: This program provides funding to Skills Tasmania endorsed registered training organisations to help them deliver nationally recognised training.
whoCanApply: Skills Tasmania endorsed registered training organisations.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $150,000.
overview: This program provides funding for nationally-recognised training in skill sets that meet: an immediate or unexpected industry or enterprise training need, and/or an immediate or unexpected learner training need in a particular region or for a particular cohort. Skills Tasmania endorsed registered training organisations are eligible to apply. Eligible applicants must meet each of the following criteria both at the time of applying, and for the duration of any subsequent funding agreement: be a Skills Tasmania endorsed registered training organisation be financially viable, and have the qualification(s) and/or unit(s) of competency included on their scope of registration for delivery in Tasmania.
whoCanApplyDetail: Skills Tasmania endorsed registered training organisations.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of up to $150,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Train Now Fund TAS
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for NSW businesses to procure battery electric vehicles (BEVs) and smart chargers
programName: Electric Vehicle Fleets Incentive: Kick-start Funding NSW
description: This program provides incentives for NSW businesses to procure BEVs and smart chargers.
whoCanApply: Eligible organisations and businesses operating car fleets in NSW.
whatYouGet: Varying amounts of funding depending on what was procured.
overview: Funding is available to support organisations to test electric vehicles in the early stage of their fleet transition. Incentives vary depending on the vehicle: Passenger Vehicle (PV)/Sports Utility Vehicle (SUV) – $5,000 per vehicle, $1,200 per charging port. Light Commercial Vehicle (LCV) up to 4.5 tonnes (e.g. utes, small vans) – $8,000 per vehicle, $1,200 per charging port. Light trucks, up to 4.5 tonnes – $10,000 per vehicle, $3,000 per charging port. Eligible applicants include: any organisation that operates a fleet of at least 3 vehicles (ICE vehicles or hybrid, or PHEV, or BEV) in NSW to support their operations, or any organisation or individual that owns at least one licensed taxi in NSW.
whoCanApplyDetail: Eligible organisations and businesses operating car fleets in NSW.
whatYouGetDetail: Varying amounts of funding depending on what was procured.

apply.text: Apply for the Electric Vehicle Fleets Incentive: Kick-start Funding NSW
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for primary producers to recover from northern and central QLD monsoon and flooding
programName: North Queensland Restocking, Replanting and On-Farm Infrastructure Grants
description: This program provides funding to primary producers impacted by northern and central Queensland monsoon and flooding, 20 December 2022–30 April 2023, to help with recovery costs.
whoCanApply: Primary producers impacted by the northern and central Queensland monsoon and flooding.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $150,000.
overview: Funding may be used to: restock livestock lost as a direct consequence of the disaster event transport or freight costs associated with replacement of lost livestock restore or replace lost or damaged on-farm infrastructure. To be eligible, applicants must own a primary production enterprise in one of the following local government areas: Boulia Shire Council Burke Shire Council Carpentaria Shire Council Cloncurry Shire Council Doomadgee Aboriginal Shire Council Mornington Shire Council Mount Isa Shire Council. Additionally, applicants must: be able to demonstrate and have verified the losses suffered as a direct result from the disaster event be able to make the required co-contribution of cash funds to match the grant funds requested have been approved for a grant under the Extraordinary Disaster Assistance Recovery Grants Scheme prior to making an application for this program demonstrate the ongoing viability of their primary production enterprise.
whoCanApplyDetail: Primary producers impacted by the northern and central Queensland monsoon and flooding.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of up to $150,000.

apply.text: Apply for the North Queensland Restocking, Replanting and On-Farm Infrastructure Grants
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Co-funding for the cost of electric vehicle (EV) recharging infrastructure
programName: Charge Up Workplace EV Charging Grants WA
description: This program provides organisations with co-funding to help them with the costs of installing EV charging equipment at their workplace.
whoCanApply: SMEs, charities and NFPs and local governments.
whatYouGet: Funding amounts vary.
overview: The types of charging situations expected to be funded in this round include: charging employee EVs – charging EVs that are primarily used by the eligible organisation's employees to commute to and from work fleet charging – charging EVs owned by the eligible organisation that are primarily used to undertake the activities of the organisation within operating hours destination charging – charging EVs owned by customers or other visitors to an eligible organisation’s premises (for example, to shop, dine or recreate) public charging – chargers that are open to the public at large. Applications will be accepted from the following types of organisations: small to medium enterprises not-for-profits registered with the Australian charities and not-for-profits commission (ACNC) local government authorities. To be eligible, applicants must intend to: use the EV charger to charge during daytime hours (9am to 5pm) or overnight (9pm to 9am) install the EV charger at a location within WA. In general, charging that occurs mainly during the evening peak of 5pm to 9pm will not be supported by this grant.
whoCanApplyDetail: SMEs, charities and NFPs and local governments.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding amounts vary.

apply.text: Apply for the Charge Up Workplace EV Charging Grants WA
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for VIC timber industry businesses to transition from native timber harvesting
description: This program provides grants for native timber industry businesses to explore, invest and implement opportunities to support their transition away from native timber harvesting.
whoCanApply: Victorian native timber industry businesses.
whatYouGet: Grants of up to $1 million.
overview: Funding is available to support businesses directly impacted by the Victorian Forestry Plan to: explore, investigate, and implement business transition opportunities undertake capital investment in business transition projects diversify and reorientate core business activities to support alternative employment opportunities develop and implement downstream manufacturing opportunities using alternative fibre invest in new opportunities to process or manufacture using plantation timber feedstock and/or alternative fibre. Applicants must: have an Australian business number (ABN) conduct business operations in Victoria meet all industrial relations obligations as an employer in accordance with the National Employment Standards (NES). You must also have or had one of the following: a current VicForests Timber Supply Agreement a Forest Produce Licence issued by VicForests a current VicForests Agreement for your Timber harvest and/or haulage business.
whoCanApplyDetail: Victorian native timber industry businesses.
whatYouGetDetail: Grants of up to $1 million.

apply.text: Apply for the Timber Innovation Grants VIC
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for NT businesses to invest in equipment or technology to reduce waste
description: This program supports businesses to reduce their waste and help the Territory transition towards a circular economy.
whoCanApply: NT businesses.
whatYouGet: Funding between $1,000 and $20,000.
overview: Funding is available for businesses to purchase equipment or technology aimed at reducing waste and improving recycling outcomes. Eligible works includes procurement of commercial equipment or technology that meets program objectives to: avoid or prevent waste from being generated on site reuse waste either on site or by another business improve source separation and facilitate waste recycling. Examples of commercial equipment or technology that may be funded include, but are not limited to: cardboard perforators commercial worm farms small scale compactors, granulators or shredders organics rapid decomposition units food and waste monitoring equipment. To be eligible, organisations must: be a Territory enterprise, either a for-profit or not-for-profit business have been operating in the NT for more than 12 months have an existing commercial waste collection service at a site in the NT be fully compliant with its obligations under its governing legislation.
whoCanApplyDetail: NT businesses.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding between $1,000 and $20,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Sustainable Business Solutions NT
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Sponsorship for heritage event and activity organisers
description: This program provides partnerships and funding to event and activity organisers in return for assisting with the delivery of one or more of the Heritage Council's key strategic outcomes.
whoCanApply: Heritage organisations.
whatYouGet: Funding and sponsorship.
overview: Heritage Council sponsorships deliver partnerships that will support heritage in Western Australia. Organisers of events or activities can apply for funding in return for assisting with the delivery of one or more of the Heritage Council's key strategic outcomes. Any organisation, not-for-profit, local government or commercial entity operating an event or activity that supports one or more of the required heritage outcomes may apply. Individuals cannot apply. Sponsored activities must meet one or more of the following outcomes: demonstrate sustainability and economic benefits of heritage conservation and adaptation deliver or contribute to training and education in heritage conservation management develop understanding of the importance of heritage and its conservation contribute to brand awareness for a nominated Heritage Council or a Department brand within relevant market sectors. promote community understanding of, and engagement with, the State’s heritage places promote and encourage heritage tourism make other demonstrated contribution to the Heritage Council and Department's strategic objectives.
whoCanApplyDetail: Heritage organisations.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding and sponsorship.

apply.text: Apply for the Heritage Sponsorship Program WA
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for boutique or mobile abattoirs in WA
programName: Small Scale Abattoir Feasibility Voucher Program WA
description: This program is aimed at those considering establishing, operating or supplying to a boutique or mobile abattoir in Western Australia
whoCanApply: WA boutique or mobile abattoirs.
whatYouGet: Vouchers of up to $10,000.
overview: Funding is available to seek expert advice and planning from professional consultants, to address the feasibility of the establishment, operation or supply to a boutique or mobile abattoir in WA. Eligible expenses could include, but are not limited to: market analysis of supply and demand factors (e.g. continuity of supply) potential costs around infrastructure and ongoing maintenance analysis of the operational model and/or regulatory requirements potential locations and investigation of site suitability potential business structures. To be eligible, applicants must: operate as an individual, sole trader, partnership, trust, cooperative or private company be based in, and be looking to investigate the feasibility of a project located in, regional and/or metropolitan WA be capable of entering into a legally binding agreement with the WA government have attended or intend to attend a facilitated session with the department be able to meet the required co-contribution.
whoCanApplyDetail: WA boutique or mobile abattoirs.
whatYouGetDetail: Vouchers of up to $10,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Small Scale Abattoir Feasibility Voucher Program WA
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for Tasmanian-based advanced manufacturing enterprises
description: This program provides Tasmanian advanced manufacturing enterprises with funding to undertake productivity-enhancing activities.
whoCanApply: Tasmanian-based advanced manufacturing enterprises.
whatYouGet: Funding between $1,500 and $20,000.
overview: Matched funding is available to Tasmanian-based advanced manufacturing enterprises to undertake productivity-enhancing activities, including: obtaining expert advice quality assurance accreditation developing staff and business skills. To be eligible, you must: be a Tasmanian-based advanced manufacturing enterprise or a high-tech, Tasmanian based business that supports manufacturing inputs such as software or component development necessary for an advanced product have an Australian business number (ABN) be registered for goods and services tax (GST) have annual sales turnover greater than $500,000 and less than $55 million in at least one of the last 2 financial years not be a consultant or intermediary not be subject to any legal disability, including bankruptcy or liquidation.
whoCanApplyDetail: Tasmanian-based advanced manufacturing enterprises.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding between $1,500 and $20,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Advanced Manufacturing Productivity Grant TAS
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Support for SA grazier and broadacre farm businesses
description: This program provides SA grazier and broadacre farm businesses with funded access to expert advisers to help them recover and adapt to climate and other challenges.
whoCanApply: SA primary production businesses.
whatYouGet: Support and mentoring.
overview: Applicants can access funded support from expert advisers in the form of on-farm assistance and group workshops to help businesses recover and adapt to climate and other challenges. AgRi-Silience consists of a series of 3 workshops (3 days) and a one-on-one coaching review with the local facilitator. Workshops will focus on: strategic farm business management and planning farm risk management and informed decision-making natural resource management personal and social resilience. Participants of AgRi-Silience will have the opportunity to access financial assistance from PIRSA (up to the value of $1000 ex. GST) to cover the costs of travel and childcare incurred as a result of participation in the program. To participate in the program, applicants must: trade as a primary production business undertake all aspects of the business wholly within Australia have an Australian business number (ABN) and be registered for goods and services tax (GST) farm in one of the agricultural regions in South Australia be established under the legal structure of a sole trader, trust, partnership, or private company.
whoCanApplyDetail: SA primary production businesses.
whatYouGetDetail: Support and mentoring.

apply.text: Apply for the AgRi-Silience Program SA
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Rebates for SA saleyards and processors for equipment and infrastructure
programName: Sheep and Goat eID Implementation Essential Equipment and Infrastructure Rebate SA
description: This program provides rebates to SA saleyards and processors to help them purchase essential equipment and infrastructure.
whoCanApply: Saleyards and processors in SA.
whatYouGet: 75% rebate on the total cost of essential equipment (including hardware and software) and infrastructure to meet obligations for the movement of sheep and farmed goats.
overview: As part of the national transition to electronic identification (eID) for sheep and goats, a rebate is available to assist saleyards and processors set up the essential equipment and infrastructure required to enable them to scan and meet their regulatory obligations under the National Livestock Identification System (NLIS) for recording and reporting individual sheep and farmed goat movements. To be eligible for the rebate, saleyards and processors must have an active South Australian saleyard or processor property identification code (PIC) and have an active NLIS database account. Saleyards and processors must: be a currently operating saleyard or processor that receives sheep or farmed goats for sale or processing be based in South Australia hold an active Australian business number (ABN) and be registered for goods and services tax (GST) be a legal entity capable of entering into a funding agreement with the Minister not have received funding from another South Australian or Australian Government program for the same activities be installing the essential infrastructure and equipment at saleyards or processing facilities located in South Australia.
whoCanApplyDetail: Saleyards and processors in SA.
whatYouGetDetail: 75% rebate on the total cost of essential equipment (including hardware and software) and infrastructure to meet obligations for the movement of sheep and farmed goats.

apply.text: Apply for the Sheep and Goat eID Implementation Essential Equipment and Infrastructure Rebate SA
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Support to purchase and install eID tagging systems in Tasmania
programName: Sheep and Goat Electronic Identification (eID) Support Scheme TAS
description: Support is available for Tasmanian sheep and goat producers, veterinarians, organisations and school farms to help with the costs of implementing eID tagging systems.
whoCanApply: Sheep and goat producers, veterinarians, organisations and school farms.
whatYouGet: Reimbursement amounts vary.
overview: Funding is available to help producers, businesses and organisations meet new requirements for scanning of electronic tags, and uploading of data to the National Livestock Identification System (NLIS) database. To be eligible for this funding round, you must have a Property Identification Code (PIC) corresponding to one of the following groups: sheep and goat owners veterinarians that treat sheep or goats school farms agricultural show societies organisations that run sheep or goat livestock events not-for-profit organisations local government. Additionally, applicants must: have an Australian business number (ABN) operate as a sole trader, partnership, trust, or private company have or agree to register for a National Livestock Identification System (NLIS) account have a business operating in Tasmania.
whoCanApplyDetail: Sheep and goat producers, veterinarians, organisations and school farms.
whatYouGetDetail: Reimbursement amounts vary.

apply.text: Apply for the Sheep and Goat Electronic Identification (eID) Support Scheme TAS

programName: Solar for Multi Dwellings Grant NT
description: This program provides funding to NT owners of units/apartments for installation of shared rooftop solar systems.
whoCanApply: NT management corporations for multi dwellings.
whatYouGet: Funding amounts vary.
overview: Funding is available to unit management corporations to cover up to 50% of the total installation costs for: a shared solar PV system solar sharing technology smart meters battery storage systems. To be eligible, applicants must be a management corporation in line with the Unit Titles Act 1975, the Unit Title Schemes Act 2009 or any other shared property management entity.
whoCanApplyDetail: NT management corporations for multi dwellings.

title: Energy bill payment for NSW small businesses
programName: National Energy Bill Relief for Small Businesses (2024-25) NSW
description: This program provides energy bill relief for NSW small businesses and charitable organisations operating in embedded networks.
whoCanApply: NSW small businesses in an embedded electricity network.
whatYouGet: One-off payment of $325.
overview: Eligible NSW small businesses who are embedded network (on-supply) customers can apply for a National Energy Bill Relief payment of up to $325 in financial year 2024-25. To be eligible, businesses must: have not already received the National Energy Bill Relief payment in the 2024-2025 financial year be in an embedded electricity network in NSW have an electricity account in the name of the business with at least 90 days of metered electricity usage uses less than 100 megawatt hours (MWh) of electricity per year across all sites in NSW have an active Australian business number (ABN).
whoCanApplyDetail: NSW small businesses in an embedded electricity network.
whatYouGetDetail: One-off payment of $325.

title: Rebates for sheep and farmed goat producers to purchase electronic identification (eID) devices
description: This program provides rebates to sheep and farmed goat producers who purchase eligible eID devices and tags.
whoCanApply: Sheep and farmed goat producers in SA.
whatYouGet: 50% rebates up to a cap of $0.95 (GST exclusive) per eligible tag.
overview: The rebate for sheep and farmed goat electronic identification (eID) has been expanded to include all 8 colours in the National Livestock Identification System (NLIS) year-of-birth (YOB) colour system for accredited eID tags. Applications are open to SA sheep and goat producers who purchase eligible NLIS-accredited tags not designated for the current year. The eID device rebate is open to South Australian sheep and farmed goat producers who: have an active property identification code (PIC) registered with PIRSA purchased NLIS-accredited eID tags in 2023 that were not sky blue purchase NLIS-accredited eID tags that do not align to the designated YOB colour provide invoices and proof of payment for purchases between 1 January 2023 and 30 June 2025.
whoCanApplyDetail: Sheep and farmed goat producers in SA.
whatYouGetDetail: 50% rebates up to a cap of $0.95 (GST exclusive) per eligible tag.

apply.text: Apply for the Expanded eID Device Rebates SA
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Mentoring and funding for NT businesses to commercialise an innovative product or service
description: The Business Innovation Program helps Northern Territory businesses to develop and commercialise innovation concepts.
whoCanApply: Northern Territory startups and entrepreneurs.
whatYouGet: Up to $30,000 in government grant funding, $2,000 in advisory services from a pre-approved advisor, and $10,000 for expenses incurred in commercialising your innovation.
overview: This program is run in 3 stages: Planning – access to mentoring support to help determine if your proposed innovation concept can progress to the next stage Development – financial assistance and mentoring to develop a viable prototype of your product Commercialisation – determining the value of your product by application in your existing business and through market research. Applicants must progress through one stage to get to the next. To be eligible, you must: have a registered Australian business number (ABN) be operating in the Northern Territory and engaged in the production of goods and services within the NT have a significant permanent presence or permanent base within the NT.
whoCanApplyDetail: Northern Territory startups and entrepreneurs.
whatYouGetDetail: Up to $30,000 in government grant funding, $2,000 in advisory services from a pre-approved advisor, and $10,000 for expenses incurred in commercialising your innovation.

apply.text: Apply for the Business Innovation Program NT
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for Tasmanian businesses to create trade opportunities
description: The Accelerating Trade Grant Program provides businesses with funding on a co-contribution basis to support activities that will lead to new trade opportunities.
whoCanApply: Tasmanian businesses.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $10,000.
overview: The Accelerating Trade Grant Program provides Tasmanian businesses with funding to help them undertake activities which will lead to new trade opportunities. Eligible activities may include: market research and business-matching services promotional activities and materials in-bound buyer visits to Tasmania travel to an off-island market on-ground expenditure. To be eligible, you must: have an Australian business number (ABN) and be registered for goods and services tax (GST) be a Tasmanian business that is producing, transforming or value-adding to products and/or services in Tasmania and be dispatching them from Tasmania demonstrate the necessary capabilities, resources and capacity to undertake the trade development activity have an annual sales turnover greater than $150,000 in at least one of the 2 last financial years, or in the current financial year-to-date, and annual sales that have never exceeded $10 million be running a financially viable business.
whoCanApplyDetail: Tasmanian businesses.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of up to $10,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Accelerating Trade Grant Program TAS
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Sponsorship for waste recovery innovation projects in TAS
programName: Waste Resource Recovery Board Sponsorship Program TAS
description: This program provides sponsorship to TAS organisations whose work, event, or project demonstrates innovation in recovering resources from waste that would otherwise be lost to landfill.
whoCanApply: Tasmanian waste management organisations.
whatYouGet: Sponsorship of up to $10,000.
overview: Sponsorships are available for projects and events that demonstrate and road-test innovation, produce improved resource streams and circular supply chains, and deliver better services, products and outcomes for Tasmania. Eligible sponsorship proponents must: be located in, and have substantial operations within Tasmania nominate the principal applicant have a track record of operating legally in accordance with relevant environmental and planning permits disclose any past convictions contravening any environmental management or land use planning legislation in the last 5 years be able to demonstrate appropriate Work Cover and public liability insurance for the proposed project. Eligible sponsorship proposals must: be geographically located in Tasmania, and be for the benefit of Tasmanians include project activities that will improve collection, sorting, reuse, repair, processing, recycling and/or remanufacturing capacity in Tasmania include relevant business planning commensurate with the scale, purpose and potential risks associated with the project, activity or organisation include projects, acquisitions and activities relating to improved facilities, equipment and/or systems include details of waste avoidance/reduction/reuse/recycling measures being incorporated into the project delivery.
whoCanApplyDetail: Tasmanian waste management organisations.
whatYouGetDetail: Sponsorship of up to $10,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Waste Resource Recovery Board Sponsorship Program TAS
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for TAS primary producers impacted by the severe weather event commencing 26 August 2024
programName: Primary Producer Emergency Response Grant Program TAS
description: This program provides funding to TAS primary producers impacted by the severe weather event commencing 26 August 2024.
whoCanApply: TAS primary producers impacted by the severe weather event commencing 26 August 2024.
whatYouGet: Funding amounts vary.
overview: Funding is available to help primary producers impacted by the severe weather event: with the costs of clean-up and reinstatement to continue or recommence operations as soon as possible where the impact has been severe. The maximum grant amount available is $10,000 (GST exclusive) to eligible primary producers state-wide for the costs associated with eligible activities to undertake clean-up and recovery. An additional amount of $15,000 is available for primary producers in the Derwent Valley and Central highlands LGAs provided evidence can demonstrate additional expenses have been incurred for clean-up and recovery following the flood and severe weather event. To be eligible, applicants must: be a primary producer hold an Australian business number (ABN) at the time of the severe weather event commencing 26 August 2024 have been engaged in carrying on the primary production enterprise when affected by the event derive at least 50% of your gross income from primary production have a primary enterprise that is located in the defined area for the event and have suffered direct damage as a result of the eligible disaster be primarily responsible for meeting the costs claimed.
whoCanApplyDetail: TAS primary producers impacted by the severe weather event commencing 26 August 2024.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding amounts vary.

apply.text: Apply for the Primary Producer Emergency Response Grant Program TAS
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Rebates for livestock agents to purchase essential electronic identification (eID) equipment
programName: Sheep and Goat eID Implementation Essential Equipment Rebate (Agents) SA
description: This program provides rebates to livestock agents who purchase eligible eID equipment.
whoCanApply: Livestock agents in SA.
whatYouGet: 75% rebates up to a cap of $7,000 (ex GST).
overview: Rebates are available to assist with the purchase costs of essential equipment required to notify stock movement under the National Livestock Identification System (NLIS). Agents may apply for a rebate to a maximum of $7,000 for the cost of essential equipment, including: pocket readers stick readers or wands mobile panel reader scanner component of a weigh crate. To be eligible, agents must be based in SA and have an: active SA livestock agent property identification code active NLIS database account.
whoCanApplyDetail: Livestock agents in SA.
whatYouGetDetail: 75% rebates up to a cap of $7,000 (ex GST).

apply.text: Apply for the Sheep and Goat eID Implementation Essential Equipment Rebate (Agents) SA
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Rebates for producers to purchase essential electronic identification (eID) equipment
programName: Sheep and Goat eID Implementation Essential Equipment Rebate (Producers) SA
description: This program provides rebates to producers who purchase eligible eID equipment.
whoCanApply: Sheep and goat producers in SA.
whatYouGet: Rebate amounts vary.
overview: South Australian producers can apply for a rebate on the costs of equipment needed to conduct and report property to property (P2P) movements under the National Livestock Identification System (NLIS). Eligible producers can apply for up to 75% of the cost of essential equipment. The rebate amount is determined by the average head movement to your property directly from another property (P2P) over a consecutive 3-year period, either: calendar years (2021,2022, 2023 or 2022, 2023, 2024) financial years (2021–22, 2022–23, 2023–24) immediate past 3 years. Based on the average count, you can apply for: up to $500 for 100 or fewer animals annually up to $2,000 for 101 to 5,000 animals annually up to $20,000 for more than 5,000 animals annually. The rebate is open to South Australian sheep and farmed goat producers who: have an active property identification code (PIC) have an active NLIS database account linked to their PIC. Applicants must be able to provide evidence of purchases and recent livestock movement.
whoCanApplyDetail: Sheep and goat producers in SA.
whatYouGetDetail: Rebate amounts vary.

apply.text: Apply for the Sheep and Goat eID Implementation Essential Equipment Rebate (Producers) SA
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding for agribusinesses to expand, diversify or relocate their value-add processing operations in Western Australia
programName: Value Add Investment Grants – Feasibility Stream WA
description: This program provides agriculture, food and beverage businesses with funding to help them implement capital investment projects to expand, diversify or relocate their value adding and processing operations in Western Australia.
whoCanApply: Agriculture, food and beverage businesses.
whatYouGet: Funding of between $15,000 and $100,000.
overview: This stream provides funding to eligible applicants for the planning, feasibility and other de-risking activities to support future capital investment of agribusiness projects. Funding may be used to access professional services to assess the feasibility of their planned investment projects and to gather other information to support their investment decision. The types of services that can be funded include: technical consultants professional services including, accounting, tax, legal and other services property related services including architect, planners, designers and valuers product or market analysts and advisors specialist reports and data services as may be applicable other advisors or relevant service providers obtaining regulatory approvals obtaining licences necessary to grow operations. To be eligible, applicants must be private sector organisations that: are registered with ASIC or registered for an Australian business number (ABN) have an annual sales turnover of at least $100,000 are located in, or are looking to relocate to, Western Australia including the Perth-metropolitan area are capable of entering into a legally binding agreement with the Western Australian Government have the financial capacity to fund the minimum cash contribution of 50% have been in operation for a minimum of 2 years (or similar established track record).
whoCanApplyDetail: Agriculture, food and beverage businesses.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of between $15,000 and $100,000.

apply.text: Apply for the Value Add Investment Grants – Feasibility Stream WA
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Support for commercial horticulture businesses in the Gnangara groundwater allocation plan area
programName: Gnangara Horticulture Water Use Efficiency Grants and Voucher Program WA
description: This program supports horticulture businesses in the Gnangara groundwater allocation plan area to implement water use efficiency measures.
whoCanApply: Commercial horticulture businesses in the Gnangara groundwater allocation plan area.
whatYouGet: Grants up to $100,000 and vouchers up to $5,000.
overview: This support program consists of grants to implement water use efficiency activities and a voucher program to engage a water efficiency expert for specialist advice to develop a plan to implement water use efficiency measures. Any of the following listed activities may be funded: modifications to irrigation systems that increase the distribution uniformity changing from sprinkler to drip irrigation purchase and implementation of soil and/or crop sensor technology crop monitoring equipment and annual data hosting fees installation of protected cropping options, which may include greenhouses, glasshouses, shade houses, windbreaks, or permanent netting soil amelioration strategies and inputs obtaining expert advice on water use efficiency. To be eligible, you must: own, share-farm or lease a property that you use for commercial horticulture production (lessee of property must provide landlord consent in writing) have a commercial horticultural property located in an eligible groundwater subareas, and is subject to the 10% reduction to groundwater abstraction from 2028 under the 2022 Gnangara groundwater allocation plan conduct the majority of your primary production business in Western Australia operate as a sole trader, partnership, trust or private company hold a current Australian business number (ABN) and are registered for goods and services tax (GST).
whoCanApplyDetail: Commercial horticulture businesses in the Gnangara groundwater allocation plan area.
