title: Funding for major events that promote tourism in WA
description: Major Events Funding provides funding for event managers and organisers to run major events which promote tourism in WA.
whoCanApply: Event managers and organisations.
whatYouGet: Funding varies on a case-by-case basis.
overview: Major Events Funding provides funding for major events on a case-by-case basis. Tourism WA assesses proposed events to determine whether it meets the funding criteria. The funding criteria include, but are not limited to: economic impact – the anticipated number of interstate and international participants, visitors, support teams and others, the length of their stay and estimated expenditure media impact – the media profile the event can raise for WA as a tourist destination event Frequency – regularly staged events will receive more favourable consideration private sector investment – the greater the funding by the private sector, the more favourable the assessment Applications must be submitted 12 months before the date of the event. Those wishing to put on a major event for locals and visitors in WA can apply.
whoCanApplyDetail: Event managers and organisations.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding varies on a case-by-case basis.

apply.text: Apply for the Major Events Funding WA
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Bonds for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander businesses
description: Performance Bonds provide bonds as security to help Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander owned businesses fulfil contracts.
whoCanApply: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander owned businesses.
whatYouGet: Performance or warranty bonds.
overview: Indigenous Business Australia (IBA) can either issue bonds directly to your buyer or provide cash security to a bank who will issue the bonds. The types of bonds that IBA can provide include: Performance bonds – give the buyer of your product or service assurance that if you don’t meet your obligations under a contract, the buyer can call on the bond to reduce its losses. Warranty bonds – protect your buyer from loss if you don’t meet your contractual warranty latent defects period (usually 12 months), after the contract is completed. To be eligible, businesses must: be 50% Indigenous owned and controlled have a track record of profitability and successful completion of similar projects be incorporated or be a partnership/joint venture between incorporated entities demonstrate capable management, including contract management have an adequate credit history.
whoCanApplyDetail: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander owned businesses.
whatYouGetDetail: Performance or warranty bonds.

apply.text: Apply for the Performance Bonds
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Loans for Tasmanian farmers and agribusinesses
description: The AgriGrowth Loan Scheme provides farm businesses, young farmers and agribusinesses with low interest loans when normal banking arrangements are not available.
whoCanApply: Tasmanian farmers and agribusinesses.
whatYouGet: Low interest loans from $100,000 to $3 million.
overview: The AgriGrowth Loan Scheme is an initiative of the Tasmanian Government providing low interest loans to Tasmanian farm businesses, young farmers and agri-food businesses. It will support projects that advance the government's Agrivision 2050 plan which aims to increase the value of the agriculture and agri-food sectors in Tasmania. Low interest loans of $100,000 to $3 million are available. Loans are usually offered over a term of 5 years at a variable interest rate, with interest only payments available for the term of the loan. Young farmers may only access loans of up to $250,000. Successful applicants may receive up to 5 hours of free professional business planning or relevant advice. To be eligible, you must be a Tasmanian farm business, young farmer or an agri-food business and: operate as a sole trader, trust, partnership or private company show a clear need for the loan include a minimum 3-year business plan that satisfies the department show ongoing financial viability with the loan application and business plan show that the venture will be make a profit within the agreed loan period have an Australian business number (ABN) and be registered for goods and services tax (GST). Farm businesses must have at least 1 member of the farm business who: is a farmer and who generally contributes at least 50% of his or her labour generally derives at least 50% of his or her income from the farm business during the term of the loan. Additionally, young farmers will: generally, be no more than 45 years old preferably not previously have been principal of a farm business and/or owned land for that purpose have suitable farming experience and be involved in the day-to-day operation of the farm.
whoCanApplyDetail: Tasmanian farmers and agribusinesses.
whatYouGetDetail: Low interest loans from $100,000 to $3 million.

apply.text: Apply for the AgriGrowth Loan Scheme TAS
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Opportunity to procure a government solution in the NT
description: This program provides opportunities and funding for organisations able to solve challenges set by the NT government.
whoCanApply: NT enterprises and organisations.
whatYouGet: The chance to negotiate a procurement contract with the NT government, and $100,000 seed funding on finalisation of a procurement contract.
overview: Challenges will be published on the NT Innovation website. The challenges will focus on solving the needs of one or more government agencies. Businesses must form a cluster to submit a solution to a challenge. This means partnering with: 2 or more NT businesses at least one research organisation any other organisations needed to deliver the solution. Organisations may be public or private. Successful applicants get: the chance to negotiate a procurement contract with the NT government $100,000 seed funding once a procurement contract is finalised. Applicants must be, or be able to form, an innovation cluster and: have a registered ABN (Australian business number) include participants located in the NT that will actively participate in the project. The members of the cluster must be physically co-located in the NT at least until any agreement has been fully completed. An innovation cluster must include two or more Territory enterprises and at least one research organisation (public or private).
whoCanApplyDetail: NT enterprises and organisations.
whatYouGetDetail: The chance to negotiate a procurement contract with the NT government, and $100,000 seed funding on finalisation of a procurement contract.

apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Customs duty refund for exporters
description: The Duty Drawback Scheme provides exporters with a refund of customs duty paid on unused imported goods, or goods that will be treated, processed or incorporated into other goods for export.
whoCanApply: Exporters.
whatYouGet: Drawback amounts vary.
overview: The Duty Drawback Scheme allows exporters to get a refund on customs duty paid on imported goods, where those goods are: to be treated, processed, or incorporated in other goods for export, or are exported unused since importation. The minimum claim per application for duty drawback is $100. To be eligible, you must be the legal owner of the goods at the time the goods are exported. Duty drawback is available on most goods on which customs duty was paid on importation and which has been exported. Please note that if making a duty drawback claim on tobacco goods then additional requirements will need to be met, including, but not limited to, lodging the claim within 12 months after the day on which the goods were exported.
whoCanApplyDetail: Exporters.
whatYouGetDetail: Drawback amounts vary.

apply.text: Apply for the Duty Drawback Scheme
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Relief from energy charges for drought-declared farms
programName: Drought Relief from Electricity Charges Scheme (DRECS) QLD
description: The Drought Relief from Electricity Charges Scheme (DRECS) provides Queensland drought-declared farming businesses with relief from supply charges on electricity used to pump water for farm or irrigation purposes.
whoCanApply: Drought-declared Queensland farming businesses.
whatYouGet: Relief from energy charges.
overview: Drought Relief from Electricity Charges Scheme provides drought-declared farming businesses with relief from supply charges on electricity accounts that are used to pump water for farm or irrigation purposes. Waivers or reimbursements of supply charges on all relevant electricity accounts are available. To be eligible, you must: be a farmer of a property that has been individually drought-declared or is within a drought-declared area be experiencing disruptions to pumping water for farming or irrigation (i.e. have no water or water availability is severely restricted within the billing period) complete and submit an application form
whoCanApplyDetail: Drought-declared Queensland farming businesses.

title: Funding opportunities for research and innovation to benefit rural industries
description: AgriFutures provides funding to organisations to deliver research and innovations that aim to strengthen and future-proof established and emerging rural industries.
whoCanApply: Organisations conducting research and delivering innovation that aims to strengthen and future-proof established and emerging rural industries.
whatYouGet: Funding varies depending on the RFQ or Open Call.
overview: AgriFutures Australia is one of 15 Research and Development Corporations (RDCs) that service the Research, Development and Extension (RD&E) needs of Australian rural industries. AgriFutures Australia has a unique role among the RDCs. AgriFutures provides funding to organisations to conduct RD&E on behalf of rural industries that pay levies to the Australian Government, but do not have their own dedicated RDC: chicken meat rice honeybee and pollination ginger tea tree oil pasture seeds export fodder thoroughbred horses kangaroo buffalo deer goat fibre ratite. Funding is also available to help establish, scale and grow emerging rural industries – that is, those that are not required to pay primary industry levies and charges to fund R&D. Each year Agrifutures Australia identifies different “target industries” for investment through their Emerging Industries Program. To be eligible to apply for an Open Call for research, you must: be conducting research which is of direct benefit to the specified Australian rural industry comply with all reporting requirements agree to disseminate valuable project intellectual property and project material in accordance with the research proposal. To submit a funding enquiry when Open Calls are closed, your enquiry must: align with the current AgriFutures Australia Research and Innovation Strategic Plan (2022-2027) match AgriFutures Australia’s RD&E priorities for the year(s) for which the proposal is being submitted, found in their Annual Reports and Annual Operational Plans aligns with: one of their 16 overarching strategic priorities in the Strategic Plan (linked above) current research priorities for a levied industry or an emerging industry, as outlined in their respective five-year industry RD&E plans accounts for any similar research projects (current or completed) and any pre-existing publications.
whoCanApplyDetail: Organisations conducting research and delivering innovation that aims to strengthen and future-proof established and emerging rural industries.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding varies depending on the RFQ or Open Call.

apply.text: Apply for the Agrifutures Australia RD&E Investment
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Interest free or low interest loans for low income earners
description: The ACT Microcredit Loan Program provides low income earners with interest free or low interest loans to help them start or expand an existing business.
whoCanApply: ACT residents on a low income.
whatYouGet: Interest free loans of up to $3,000 or low-interest loans of between $3,001 and $10,000.
overview: The ACT Microcredit Loan Program provides a limited number of no interest and low interest loans for suitable low-income earners who wish to start or expand an existing business. Loan recipients can also access a range of services including: one-on-one mentoring peer support access to networking events. No Interest loans To be eligible for a no interest loan, you must: have had a Health Care Card (for a period of at least 6 months), Pension Card or equivalent have a combined family income no higher than $65,000 (including de facto relationship) have been an ACT resident for minimum of 6 months (proof of residency required) be setting up a business based in the ACT. Low Interest loans To be eligible for a low interest loan, you must: have had a Health Care Card (for a period of at least 6 months), Pension Card or equivalent have a combined family income no higher than $75,000 (including de facto relationship) have been an ACT resident for a minimum of 6 months (proof of residency required) have an existing or semi established business based in the ACT.
whoCanApplyDetail: ACT residents on a low income.
whatYouGetDetail: Interest free loans of up to $3,000 or low-interest loans of between $3,001 and $10,000.

description: The Community Energy Upgrades program will co-fund energy efficiency and electrification upgrades for local governments to deliver reduced energy bills and emissions from local government owned and/or operated facilities.
whoCanApply: Local government bodies.

title: Funding for NSW companies to commercialise products or processes
description: This program provides NSW companies with funding to commercialise innovative and new products or processes.
whoCanApply: NSW companies.
whatYouGet: Funding from $25,000 to $50,000.
overview: Funding is available to help businesses progress their new products or processes along the Technology Readiness Level (TRL) scale and attract large-scale private investment. Businesses who successfully complete projects funded under the program are permitted to reapply for additional funding to make further progress along the TRL scale. To be eligible, you must: have an Australian business number (ABN) be non-tax exempt be headquartered in NSW hold intellectual property (IP) or rights to commercialise your product have an aggregated turnover of less than A$1 million for each of the 3 financial years prior to the lodgement of your application be an entity with less than or equal to 20 FTE.

title: Funding for exploration of petroleum and geothermal resources in WA
description: This program provides funding to encourage exploration of petroleum and geothermal resources in Western Australia.
whoCanApply: WA explorers and prospectors.
whatYouGet: Funding amounts vary.
overview: The Energy Analysis Program aims to support exploration of petroleum and geothermal resources in WA by providing funding under 2 categories: analysis and reprocessing – funding for analysis of existing state resources and re-analysis of existing data geophysics acquisition – funding for acquisition of greenfields geophysical data to achieve better resolution and understanding of petroleum and geothermal systems. To be eligible, applicants must: be a legal entity that can enter a legally binding funding agreement with the WA government have an active Australian company number (ACN) be registered for goods and services tax (GST) hold either a Petroleum Title, Geothermal Title or Reservation Title including a petroleum or geothermal special prospecting authority. Projects are eligible for funding must: not be retrospective be able to be completed in a 12-month period have given due consideration to the reliability of the business to complete and return all data and samples within the 12-month period be within the categories of either analysis of physical services, reprocessing or desktop and data studies.

description: The Co-funded Exploration Drilling Program provides explorers with funding for up to 50% of exploratory drilling costs.
whoCanApply: WA explorers and prospectors.
overview: The Co-funded Exploration Drilling Program provides explorers with co-funding to undertake exploratory drilling. Funding is for exploration drilling only and may not be used for: resource definition drilling appraisal, stimulation and development drilling the development of new uranium mines. Co-funding of up to 50% of direct drilling cost is available and is capped at: $180,000 for general multi-hole applications $220,000 for a single deep-hole application $40,000 for a prospector application. To be eligible, you must: have an Australian business number (ABN) be the holder of, or have access to, a tenement.

description: This program provides matched funding to small and medium-sized SA manufacturing enterprises to improve productivity and competitiveness in global markets.
whoCanApply: SA small and medium-sized manufacturing enterprises.

overview: Matched funding is available for small and medium-sized enterprises to support the adoption of innovative Industry 4.0 technologies, including: artificial intelligence machine learning and data analytics blockchain augmented and virtual reality additive manufacturing advanced composite materials robotics and automation Internet of Things quantum technologies optics and photonics other Industry 4.0 technologies which enable new manufacturing processes for decarbonisation or circular economy/closed loop systems. To be eligible to apply for this program, applicants must: be an organisation comprised of one or more legal entities (not a person); incorporated or established in Australia be a small to medium enterprise (SME), defined as having fewer than 200 full-time equivalent employees have an Australian business number (ABN) and be registered for goods and services tax (GST) be carrying on an active manufacturing business located in South Australia, demonstrated by undertaking manufacturing activities at premises located in South Australia, and employing staff based in South Australia have been carrying on a business for more than one full financial year have not previously received grant funding for the same proposed project.

description: This program provides funding to NT-based tour operators who conduct tours in Northern Territory to train new or upskill existing tour guides (entrants).
whoCanApply: NT-based tour operators.
whatYouGet: Funding of up to $5,000.
overview: The program will reimburse the applicant up to $5,000 upon completion of the relevant training components. Entrants must complete all approved training components by 30 April 2025, for applicants to receive reimbursement. To be eligible, businesses must: be legally constituted be an Australian-registered business and a Territory enterprise have a current Australian Tourism Data Warehouse (ATDW) listing have an online booking system, or be in the process of implementing one have a touring product/s that require tour guides have a permanent presence in the NT be a member of a peak industry body.

title: Funding for projects increasing information related to greenfields regions in WA
description: This program provides funding for projects that explore new mineral resources in greenfields regions of WA.
whoCanApply: WA explorers and prospectors.
whatYouGet: Matched funding of up to $250,000.
overview: The Co-funded Geophysics Program (CGP) will support geophysical exploration in the mineral resources sector. The CGP provides funding for projects that explore the WA greenfields regions for new mineral resources, including: refining regional structures including basin or province margins identifying geophysical anomalies under cover redefining regions for new deposit types defining target geometries and depth. Higher preference will be given to: greenfields projects (exploration in unexplored or underexplored areas, away from known deposits or mines) regional to camp-scale projects projects targeting critical minerals. Funding can be offered to applicants holding one of the following permits: Petroleum Title Geothermal Title Exploration Permit Application Drilling Reservation Special Prospecting Authority Special Prospecting Authority with Acreage Option Special Prospecting Authority Application. Analysis programs that will be eligible for co-funding include: analysis of physical samples reprocessing (e.g. seismic) desktop or data studies. The following activities will not be eligible for co-funding under the Energy Analysis Program: drilling campaigns wireline and sampling conducted during operational activities acquisition surveys (e.g. seismic, gravity, magnetic, ground-based geochemical surveys).

overview: PIRSA is seeking expressions of interest (EOI) from regionally-based South Australian Producer Groups to provide a supporting learning environment for sheep and farmed goat producers, to enhance capabilities and efficient use of eID. Producers will learn from experts and each other about how eID technologies and the collected data can assist with and improve livestock productivity, efficiency and profitability in their businesses. Each eID Producer Group must appoint a facilitator for the group. The facilitator will be responsible for co-ordinating and facilitating Producer Group activities, reporting progress and outcomes to PIRSA and ensuring all data collection is undertaken. Regionally-based South Australian sheep and goat producer groups can apply. Individual producers can contact PIRSA to enquire about establishing or joining an existing group. Activities eligible for funding include: workshops to upskill primary producers in eID and data-based decision making costs associated with an expert speaker presenting to the producer group associated travel costs for the producer group to conduct a field study associated travel costs of the producer group facilitator catering and venue hire for producer group events creation of resources or printing of resources to be delivered to producer groups developing an individual producer eID plan (template to be provided by PIRSA) cost of facilitator undertaking delivery of the producer groups cost of facilitator time to undertake reporting to PIRSA.

overview: The first round of the Fund will support projects that are focused on proof-of-concept or delivery of innovative space capability, with an emphasis on NewSpace. Proposals will be sought from consortia led by South Australian start-ups or Small to Medium Enterprises (SMEs) and must include an international partner. The project should address the need to advance sovereign capability in space, grow the workforce and talent in the sector and drive innovative technology solutions in the space sector. With a focus on NewSpace opportunities, projects should aim to: bring a new product or service to market grow and develop operations through accessing international opportunities provide space-related solutions to drive wider economic benefit across South Australia open doors for South Australia globally/internationally. Minimum requirements for collaboration: at least one South Australia-based industry organisation (start-up or SME) at least one international partner organisation. Minimum requirements for matched funding: 1:1 matched funding (cash or in-kind), i.e. $1 Fund to $1 provided by project participants comprise a minimum of 10% cash (the international partner is required to contribute to the matched funding element (cash or in-kind)).

overview: The Fisheries Structural Adjustment Scheme aims to support holders and lessees of eligible primary commercial fishing licences (PCFL), fishery symbol holders and skippers and crew members who are affected by the closure of certain fisheries in the Great Barrier Reef region, changes to the Great Sandy Marine Park zoning plan and the introduction of new gillnet free areas in the Gulf of Carpentaria. There are various assistance measures offered under the scheme. Eligibility criteria vary depending on the support being applied for.

title: Funding to support the development of vibrant going-out hubs
description: This program provides funding to fast-track the formation of local business communities and facilitate the growth of their districts into vibrant going-out hubs.
whoCanApply: Organisations that demonstrate unique identity and entertainment offerings.
whatYouGet: Funding of between $100,000 and $200,000.
overview: Funding will be available for eligible district teams to coordinate and promote consumer engagement activities with the following objectives: increasing coordination and collaboration between businesses in distinct geographical areas supporting business models that allow for partnerships, including major events, brands and government increasing the marketability of unique districts with distinct products developed increasing consumer awareness and engagement with districts. To be eligible, applicant district teams must: be an eligible entity be located in an eligible Local Government Area. District Teams must be or provide evidence of becoming one of the following entities to apply: incorporated association company limited by guarantee non-distributing co-operative. To be eligible, entities must also: have an applicable Australian business number (ABN) be registered for goods and services tax (GST), or provide evidence of GST registration application have a bank account with an Australian financial institution, or provide evidence of application have a minimum of 5 registered members of the applying entity based in the district have a letter of no objection from the relevant council organisation and/or contact details of a relevant representative from a local council organisation that has agreed to be contacted in relation to this application be solvent be able to execute a funding deed with the NSW Government on a successful application.
whoCanApplyDetail: Organisations that demonstrate unique identity and entertainment offerings.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding of between $100,000 and $200,000.

title: Funding for event organisers in Queensland

whatYouGet: Between $10,000 and $100,000, for either Tier 1 or Tier 2.
overview: Queensland Destination Events Program provides funding to event organisers staging events held entirely in Queensland. The event should: generate local economic activity and development in the host destination attract visitors to the region drive social and community outcomes for the region enhance the profile of the region. There are 2 tiers of funding available: destination events funding – amounts between $10,000 and $25,000 significant events funding – amounts between $25,000 and $100,000. To be eligible, you must: have an Australian business number (ABN) be either a corporation registered with ASIC, or an Incorporated Association be conducting an event that takes place entirely within Queensland. To be eligible for significant event funding, the event must be (at a minimum) in its third year.

whatYouGetDetail: Grants from $50,000 to $100,000 for a renewables and low emissions Feasibility project. If your Feasibility project is successful, you may receive up to $1 million to develop a proof of concept.

title: Funding to purchase energy efficient equipment upgrades for small and medium businesses
programName: Energy Efficiency Grants for Small and Medium Enterprises Round 2
description: The grant opportunity provides eligible small and medium businesses up to $25,000 to purchase energy efficient equipment to reduce and manage energy usage and costs.
whoCanApply: This grant opportunity is for small and medium sized businesses with an employee headcount of 1 to 199 employees.
whatYouGet: A grant of up to $25,000, to cover up to 100% of eligible expenditure. There is a total of $41.241 million available for this grant opportunity. Grant funding will be distributed between states and territories based on the distribution of small and medium sized businesses nationally. Refer to Appendix A in the grant opportunity guidelines for a breakdown of funding in each jurisdiction. We expect that there may be a high level of interest for this grant opportunity, and it may be oversubscribed. This is a demand driven grant opportunity. Grants will be awarded to eligible applicants on a first come, first served basis until the funding is exhausted in each jurisdiction.
whoCanApplyDetail: This grant opportunity is for small and medium sized businesses with an employee headcount of 1 to 199 employees.
whatYouGetDetail: A grant of up to $25,000, to cover up to 100% of eligible expenditure. There is a total of $41.241 million available for this grant opportunity.

title: Funding for skills development and training in the defence industry sector

Defence Industry Associations training their own staff or facilitating training to businesses they are representing. Defence Industry Associations applying for funding for eligible activities for the eligible businesses they are representing.
whatYouGet: A grant between $5,000 and $500,000 to undertake various defence skills training activities. You may apply for multiple grants or group multiple eligible activities into one application. The funding is capped at $500,000 in a six-year period from 2020–21 to 2025–26 for: each eligible business; and each industry association which is applying for funding to train their own staff.

Up to 50% co-funding is required for; Early Career Research Grants, Research Grants, and for Postdoctoral Fellowship Grants. The minimum grant amount for Non-salaried Researcher Grants is $5,000. whoCanApply: Eligible organisations to work in partnership with Australian small to medium-sized enterprises to progress their medical research and medical innovation projects towards commercialisation.
whatYouGet: $19.75 million for organisations to progress medical research and medical innovation projects through the early stages of development.

title: Funding for Australian Researchers to improve research data facilities and systems
programName: MRFF 2020 Primary Health Care Research Data Infrastructure Grant Opportunity
description: The initiative will fund the creation or extension of national research data infrastructure. It'll focus on strategic investment in data registries, biobanks and data linkage platforms to support world-class health and medical research in Australia.
whoCanApply: An eligible organisation in selected health care settings.
whatYouGet: Grants of between $1 million and $2 million for medical research using data infrastructure in primary care settings to improve access, quality, safety and efficiency.
whatYouGetDetail: Grants of between $1 million and $2 million for medical research using data infrastructure in primary care settings to improve access, quality, safety and efficiency.

title: Grants to improve safety and accessibility of remote airstrips
description: The Remote Airstrip Upgrade Program provides funding to improve aerodromes in remote areas of Australia. The aim is to provide year round all weather access and improve delivery of essential goods and services.
whoCanApply: Owners and operators of aerodromes in remote or very remote areas of Australia.
whatYouGet: Grants of up to $500,000 to enhance aerodrome safety and accessibility.
whoCanApplyDetail: Owners and operators of aerodromes in remote or very remote areas of Australia.
whatYouGetDetail: Grants of up to $500,000 to enhance aerodrome safety and accessibility.

title: Funding for Defence businesses who are developing new products and manufacturing processes
programName: MMI Manufacturing Integration Stream Defence round 2
description: The Manufacturing Integration Stream – Defence grant opportunity supports projects that integrate Australian businesses into domestic and international value chains which will propel their goods and services into new markets. The opportunity provides co-funding to encourage linkages between local businesses and domestic and international firms. It will also facilitate the adoption of product standards and greater knowledge sharing.
whoCanApply: Defence businesses who want to enter new markets or integrate into supply chains.
whatYouGet: Grants of between $1 million to $20 million, up to 50% of the eligible project expenditure.
whoCanApplyDetail: Defence businesses who want to enter new markets or integrate into supply chains.
whatYouGetDetail: Grants of between $1 million to $20 million, up to 50% of the eligible project expenditure.

programName: Carbon Capture Use and Storage Development Fund
description: The Carbon Capture, Use and Storage Development Fund provides businesses with grants of up $25 million for pilot projects or pre-commercial projects aimed at reducing emissions.
whoCanApply: Companies, State/Territory agencies and authorities of the Commonwealth engaging in carbon capture, use and storage (CCUS) technologies in Australia.
whatYouGet: Grants from $500,000 to $25 million.
whoCanApplyDetail: Companies, State/Territory agencies and authorities of the Commonwealth engaging in carbon capture, use and storage (CCUS) technologies in Australia.
whatYouGetDetail: Grants from $500,000 to $25 million.

title: Funding for businesses to invest in capabilities to address supply chain vulnerabilities
description: The Supply Chain Resilience Initiative provides up to $2 million to establish or scale a manufacturing capability or a related activity to address supply chain vulnerabilities for a critical product or input identified in the Sovereign Manufacturing Capability Plan.
whoCanApply: A manufacturing business or a business within the manufacturing supply chain.
whatYouGet: Grants from $50,000 to $2 million.
whoCanApplyDetail: A manufacturing business or a business within the manufacturing supply chain.
whatYouGetDetail: Grants from $50,000 to $2 million.

title: Get advice and funding to take your novel idea to market
description: Accelerating Commercialisation provided advice and funding to get your novel product, process or service to market. This program is closed.
whoCanApply: Businesses, start-ups and researchers who have a novel product, process or service ready to scale up and commercialise in global markets.
whatYouGet: You’ll be paired with an independent facilitator. Your facilitator will make recommendations to take your project from prototype to your first commercial sales and they’ll help you apply for the commercialisation grant.
whatYouGetDetail: You’ll be paired with an independent facilitator. Your facilitator will make recommendations to take your project from prototype to your first commercial sales and they’ll help you apply for the commercialisation grant.

title: Grants to boost girls' and women's participation in STEM and entrepreneurship
programName: Women in STEM and Entrepreneurship – Round 3
description: Women in STEM and Entrepreneurship grants encourage participation of girls and women in science, technology, engineering and mathematics leading to STEM education and careers.
whoCanApply: To apply you must be an organisation incorporated in Australia, a publicly funded research organisation or publicly funded research agency, a vocational education and training provider, a technical and further education institution or a not-for-profit organisation.
whatYouGet: Grants between $5,000 and $250,000 for projects that increase women’s and girls’ participation in STEM and entrepreneurship.
whoCanApplyDetail: To apply you must be an organisation incorporated in Australia, a publicly funded research organisation or publicly funded research agency, a vocational education and training provider, a technical and further education institution or a not-for-profit organisation.
whatYouGetDetail: Grants between $5,000 and $250,000 for projects that increase women’s and girls’ participation in STEM and entrepreneurship.

title: Funding for Australian businesses to start or grow their exports in international markets
description: The EMDG program provides funding to help businesses market and promote their goods and services internationally.
whoCanApply: Australian exporters and their representative bodies.
whatYouGet: Funding amounts vary.
overview: The Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) program provides matched funding to eligible Australian small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and representative bodies at different points in their export journey. Grants are to support marketing and promotional activities and training that help create, develop, expand and diversify to foreign markets for Australian products and services. EMDG can provide support depending on the business goals, export status and ability to meet eligibility requirements for the following tiers: Tier 1 – businesses ready to export Tier 2 – businesses exporting within existing markets Tier 3 – businesses exporting to new markets Representative bodies – that support members to achieve export success. Grant amounts For this grant opportunity, up to $104.5 million will be available in 2025-26 and up to $104.5 million in 2026-27 for grant allocations. Maximum grant amounts for each tier per financial year, 2025–26 and 2026–27, are: Tier 1 – $20,000 up to $30,000 per financial year Tier 2 – $20,000 up to $50,000 per financial year Tier 3 – $20,000 up to $80,000 per financial year Representative bodies – up to $50,000 per financial year for representative bodies that support SME members to achieve export success. As a business applicant For business applicants, to be eligible, you need to be an eligible Australian person and have eligible products and expenses as defined in the EMDG Rules. The EMDG Guidelines provide a simple description of the eligibility requirements. Eligibility criteria for businesses require you to: have a valid Australian business number (ABN) have conducted your business under the same ABN for at least 2 years meet a minimum annual turnover (that differs for each tier) but is less than $20 million have the capacity to spend at least $20,000 per financial year, exclusive of the grant amount. This is your own money. This cannot be funding from other Commonwealth, state, territory or local government have a high-quality plan to market that is specific to your business. It must not be copied from another business, another EMDG application or a generic marketing plan be tax compliant and fit to receive a grant meet all other eligibility requirements. As a representative body To be eligible for a grant as a representative body you must: have a valid Australian Business Number (ABN) not be distributing income to members or shareholders have a high-quality plan to market that is specific to your business, if you are planning marketing and promotional activities. Your plan must not be copied from another representative body, business, another EMDG application or a generic marketing plan have a high-quality training plan, if you are providing export training to your SME members demonstrate in your plans how your activities benefit your SME members be tax compliant and fit to receive a grant meet all other eligibility requirements.
whoCanApplyDetail: Australian exporters and their representative bodies.
whatYouGetDetail: Funding amounts vary.

apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Immediate bushfire clean-up assistance for Victorians
description: The Bushfire Clean-up Program provides free of charge clean-up assistance for the demolition and disposal of all buildings destroyed by this season's bushfires.
whoCanApply: Eligible Victorian property owners whose buildings have been destroyed or damaged beyond repair by this season's bushfires.
whatYouGet: Free demolition and disposal of destroyed buildings.
overview: Free of charge clean-up assistance is available for buildings that have been destroyed or damaged beyond repair, including: residential homes sheds and other out-buildings commercial buildings public buildings. Removal of fencing, trees and vehicles may also be included but only where necessary for the safe clean-up of destroyed buildings. This is a voluntary program and is provided free of charge for eligible property owners. You do not need to be insured to be eligible for this program.
whoCanApplyDetail: Eligible Victorian property owners whose buildings have been destroyed or damaged beyond repair by this season's bushfires.
whatYouGetDetail: Free demolition and disposal of destroyed buildings.

apply.text: Apply for the Bushfire Clean-up Program VIC
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Support for QLD scalable Indigenous native food businesses
description: The Indigenous Native Food Program provides Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander businesses and innovators with support to develop and commercialise native food products.
whoCanApply: Queensland Indigenous businesses.
whatYouGet: Support and collaboration from food experts.
overview: This pilot program aims to support applicants to: explore commercial opportunities for existing and new native food products create new products and/or market opportunities validate product concepts determine what is needed for commercial production, including: equipment processes resources formulations raw materials food safety labelling scale-up concept products for commercial production for existing or new markets Department of Agriculture and Fisheries (DAF) food experts will assist in project delivery through inspiration, collaboration and support. To be eligible, organisations must: be an Indigenous business have an Australian business number (ABN) be registered for goods and services tax (GST) at the time of applying be head-quartered in Queensland have no more than 50 full-time equivalent staff have a product-development project which is supported by a business plan and is capable of being completed within 12 months be developing a native food with the intention to rapidly scale
whoCanApplyDetail: Queensland Indigenous businesses.
whatYouGetDetail: Support and collaboration from food experts.

apply.text: Apply for the Indigenous Native Food Program QLD
apply.description: Find out more about your eligibility and how to apply.

title: Funding university research for future defence capability
programName: Australia-US International Multidisciplinary University Research Initiative (AUSMURI)
description: Australian universities participating in approved submissions on a designated topic under the US Multidisciplinary University Research Initiative (MURI) can apply for a grant. AUSMURI supports the development of fundamental and basic research to strengthen Australian university research capacity, skills, and global networks in fields of priority for future Defence capabilities.
whoCanApply: The lead Australian university in an approved MURI submission on a dedicated topic.
whatYouGet: A grant of up to AUD$1 million per year for 3 years, subject to available grant funds, to fund a research project on a designated topic.
whoCanApplyDetail: The lead Australian university in an approved MURI submission on a dedicated topic.
whatYouGetDetail: A grant of up to AUD$1 million per year for 3 years, subject to available grant funds, to fund a research project on a designated topic.
